metaData.descriptionCS: The examinee responds orally with a complete sentence to describe each photograph. Later items require the use of one or two target words or a beginning phrase.

questions.title: Sample A. A boy and his mother read a book.
†Item 1. picture of girl eating
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Here is another picture. Say a good sentence that tells about this picture.

Correct response: †Incorrect response:

Good.

If the examinee doesn’t respond, or if the response is a fragment, say, What is happening in the picture?

If needed, say, One good sentence that tells about this picture is A girl is eating.

Give more specific instructional feedback as needed.

taskErrors.label: Does not include noun/pronoun and verb

questions.title: †Item 2. picture of boy tying shoe
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Say a good sentence that tells about this picture.

Correct response: †Incorrect response:

Good.

If the examinee doesn’t respond, or if the response is a fragment, say, What is happening in the picture?

If needed, say, One good sentence that tells about this picture is The boy puts on his shoes.

Give more specific instructional feedback as needed.

taskErrors.label: Does not include noun/pronoun and verb

taskErrors.label: Does not include noun/pronoun and verb

questions.topInstructionsHTML: Say a good sentence that tells about this picture.

taskErrors.label: Does not include noun/pronoun and verb

questions.title: †Item 7. car
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Say a good sentence that tells about this picture, and use the word car (point to the word).

Correct response: †Incorrect response:

Good.

If the response doesn’t include the word car, say, Remember to use car in your sentence. Try again.

If the examinee doesn’t respond, or if the response is a fragment, say, What is happening in the picture?

If needed, say, One good sentence that tells about this picture using the word car is A young boy plays with his car.

Give more specific instructional feedback as needed.

taskErrors.label: Does not include noun/pronoun and verb

questions.title: †Item 8. cat
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Say a good sentence that tells about this picture, and use the word cat (point to the word).

Correct response: †Incorrect response:

Good.

If the response doesn’t include the word cat, say, Remember to use cat in your sentence. Try again.

If the examinee doesn’t respond, or if the response is a fragment, say, What is happening in the picture?

If needed, say, One good sentence that tells about this picture using the word cat is The girl is holding a cat.

Give more specific instructional feedback as needed.

taskErrors.label: Does not include noun/pronoun and verb

questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Say a good sentence that tells about this picture, and use the word) flowers.

taskErrors.label: Does not include noun/pronoun and verb

questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Say a good sentence that tells about this picture, and use the word) birds.

taskErrors.label: Does not include noun/pronoun and verb

questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Say a good sentence that tells about this picture, and use the word) tree.

taskErrors.label: Does not include noun/pronoun and verb

questions.title: Item 12. finally
questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Say a good sentence that tells about this picture, and use the word) finally.

taskErrors.label: Does not include noun/pronoun and verb

questions.title: †Item 13. wet, splashing
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Say a good sentence that tells about this picture, and use the words wet and splashing.

Correct response: †Incorrect response:

Good.

If the response doesn’t include both wet and splashing, say, Remember to use wet and splashing in your sentence. Try again.

If the examinee doesn’t respond, or if the response is a fragment, say, What is happening in the picture?

If needed, say, One good sentence that tells about this picture using the words wet and splashing is The girl is splashing and getting wet.

Give more specific instructional feedback as needed.

taskErrors.label: Does not include noun/pronoun and verb

(Say a good sentence that tells about this picture, and use the word) until.

‘Til is an acceptable contraction for until.

taskErrors.label: Does not include noun/pronoun and verb

questions.title: †Item 24. Even though
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
Say a good sentence that tells what’s happening in this picture, and start with the words Even though.

Correct response: †Incorrect response:

Good.

If the response doesn’t begin with Even though, say, Remember to start your sentence with Even though. Try again.

If the examinee doesn’t respond, or if the response is a fragment, say, What is happening in the picture?

If needed, say, One good sentence that tells about this picture and starts with Even though is Even though it’s raining, they still walk to work.

Give more specific instructional feedback as needed.

taskErrors.label: Does not begin with target word phrase
Does not include noun/pronoun and verb

questions.title: Item 25. Whether or not
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
(Say a good sentence that tells what’s happening in this picture, and) start with the words Whether or not.

Whether or not can be used to mean regardless or whether.

taskErrors.label: Does not begin with target word phrase
Does not include noun/pronoun and verb

questions.title: Item 26. Although they had
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
(Say a good sentence that tells what’s happening in this picture, and) start with the words Although they had.

Although they had requires past tense in the independent clause unless defined time periods are provided in both clauses.

taskErrors.label: Does not begin with target word phrase
Does not include noun/pronoun and verb

questions.title: Item 27. Only if he
questions.topInstructionsHTML:
(Say a good sentence that tells what’s happening in this picture, and) start with the words Only if he.

Only if he requires the main clause to be inverted, so that the subject comes after the verb (correct example: Only if he rests will he get better).

taskErrors.label: Does not begin with target word phrase

questions.title: Item 28. If he had
questions.topInstructionsHTML: (Say a good sentence that tells what’s happening in this picture, and) start with the words If he had.

consecutiveZerosDiscontinueRule.description: Oral expression consecutive zeroes discontinue rule
consecutiveZerosDiscontinueRule.overlayMessageHtml: This subtest is to be discontinued if 5 consecutive items within a set are scored 0 for both Task and Grammar.

BasalConsecutiveTaskZerosRule.reverseMessage: This subtest reverses after a Task score of 0 on both of the first two items.
BasalConsecutiveTaskZerosRule.taskIncompleteDescriptionHtml: A Task score must be recorded for the first two items administered after a start point.

startingPoints.label: Grades PK-1: Set A, Sample A, then Items 1-23

htmlSnippets.implicationsForIntervention:
Implications For Intervention

The Task and Grammar scores are independent of each other to help provide meaningful diagnostic information about the examinee’s strengths and weaknesses. One examinee may have weaknesses in grammar but still convey meaningful ideas that meet the Task requirements. Another examinee may have strong grammar skills but have difficulty constructing logical and meaningful sentences. These examinees would have different instructional needs.

If the examinee’s performance suggests a possible grammar weakness, completing the error analysis will indicate whether the number of errors made by the examinee indicates a normative weakness and provide even greater specificity regarding the type of grammar instruction that may be helpful.

Task comprehension is important for obtaining a valid estimate of the examinee’s oral expression skills. Take full advantage of the teaching items to help ensure the examinee understands the task. Failure to do so may result in a score that misrepresents an examinee’s grammar skills as described in the following two scenarios.

  • If an examinee speaks in fragmented sentences (e.g., a girl eating) on most or all items because he or she does not understand that a complete sentence is required for the task, the subtest score may give a false impression that the examinee has a weakness in grammar. In this case, consider testing the limits after administration is completed to determine if the examinee can produce complete sentences with additional prompting.

  • If an examinee fails to use the target words on most or all of the items and produces grammatically correct but simple responses, the subtest score may overestimate the examinee’s grammar skills. The target words are designed to increase the grammatical difficulty level of the items, so examinees who fail to use the target words may receive credit for Grammar for providing simpler responses than the items require. In this case, consider testing the limits after administration is completed to determine if the examinee can build sentences with the target words when given further instructions.
htmlSnippets.twoPointResponses-ktea3a-oralexpression-:
2-Point Responses
They feed the birds.
The lady is feeding the birds.
We fed the birds some bread.
The birds are getting fed.
Birds are eating.
Look at the birds.
They are watching the birds.

2-Point Responses
A girl is climbing a tree.
That is a girl in a tree.
The girl is hanging from the tree.
A girl is sitting in a tree.
A girl is hiding in a tree.
She is stuck in the tree.
A girl plays in a tree.
I can climb a tree.
That tree is big.

2-Point Responses
A little girl finally throws her food away.
The girl finally found a trashcan.
She finally finishes her lunch and throws it away.
A little girl is finally taking out the trash.
I’m finally done with my food.
A girl has finally finished eating.
After she ate, she finally threw her food away.
The girl is throwing something away finally.
Finally, I found a trashcan.
Finally, the park is clean.
The girl said, “Finally, I am done eating.”
The girl will drink her juice, and finally she will throw it in the trash can.

2-Point Responses
The girl is getting wet by splashing water.
She is wet because she’s splashing the water.
She’s splashing water and getting wet.
Splashing water will always get you wet.
The little girl is wet and she’s splashing.
She is splashing in the wet water. [Redundancy is not penalized]

‘Til is an acceptable contraction for until.

2-Point Responses
They are not going to cross the street ‘til the light is green.
Do not cross the street until the signal says walk.
Don’t walk until a car passes.
The family is waiting until it is clear to cross the road.
Wait until it is clear to cross the street.
Wait until the light turns red.
They are waiting on the sidewalk until the bus arrives.
Until they can walk, they stand there and wait.

2-Point Responses
The boy is above his dad’s head.
He holds the boy above his shoulders.
The boy is above his dad.
The dad can put his son above his head.
This dad is holding his child above him.
Seeing the world from his father’s shoulders made him feel above everything.

2-Point Responses
The mom talks on the phone.
The mother talks a lot.
The woman talks as she plays with her daughter.
The lady talks on the phone while the baby plays with her toy.
Mom talks on her cell phone while her daughter pretends to talk on her toy phone.
The little girl plays with her toy while her mom talks on the phone.
My baby talks when I’m on the phone.

2-Point Responses
The boy points at the clock while smiling.
He points and he is smiling.
He points while he is smiling.
A boy is smiling while he points to the clock.
While smiling, the boy points to the clock.
The smiling boy points to the clock.
The smiling boy made some good points as he explained how to tell time.

2-Point Responses
When they got there, their grandma and grandpa were waiting.
When the children arrived, the grandparents were waiting for them.
When the kids got there, their grandparents stopped waiting.
When the children saw their grandparents waiting for them, they ran into open arms.
The grandparents were done waiting when the children came.
The little kids stopped waiting when they got to their grandparents’ house.
The grandparents were waiting when the children arrived.
Grandma and grandpa were waiting for when we got there.
When they were waiting for the kids, they were happy.
The waiting grandparents were happy when the grandchildren arrived.
The kids have been waiting and they’ll run when they see their grandparents.

2-Point Responses
Without imagination and ingenuity, the child cannot reach the magnets.
Without the help of his mom, he reaches up and tries to grab the letter.
Without help he can’t reach because he’s small and short.
Without help the child can’t and won’t be able to reach the letters.
The boy cannot spell his name without the letters “k” and “e.”
The boy cannot reach the letters without his mom and dad.
The boy couldn’t reach the letters and he couldn’t play without them.
The boy reaches up and gets one down without any help.
The child is too short and he cannot reach without a stool.
The boy wants to get the magnets without help, and he can’t reach.

2-Point Responses
She was taken by her father to go floating.
The girl is taken by the current while floating in her tube.
The girl was floating when the picture was taken.
The girl gets her picture taken while floating in the pool.
After her mom has taken her picture, the girl begins floating around the water.
She hasn’t taken swimming lessons, so she is using a floating device.
Even though she has taken swimming lessons, she likes floating.
The girl had taken her floating device to go swimming in the pool.
She was floating when her tube was taken away.
After the girl had taken a tube, she was able to go floating across the water.
I have taken the tube and now I am floating.
She had taken her towel off to go floating in the water.
She has taken to floating on the water.
The girl is floating on the taken floatie.

2-Point Responses
All the kids are swinging but one.
They are swinging, but she is not.
The kids are swinging but one girl is standing.
The little girl wanted to swing, but the swings are taken.
She wants to swing, but there are not enough swings.
The boy and girl are swinging but the other girl isn’t.
There are three children but only two swings.
There are three kids, but only two are swinging.
Two of the children are swinging, but one is feeling left out.
Her friends are swinging, but she has to wait until it’s her turn.
But are you going to let me swing on the swings?
But are we going to take turns?

2-Point Responses
The man was chosen to start helping his wife.
The man is chosen to start helping his wife cook.
The woman has chosen to cut the peppers while the man is helping to cut the lettuce.
He has chosen to be helping in the kitchen.
He has chosen to give his wife a helping hand with dinner.
They have chosen to work together by helping each other.
She has chosen the peppers and he is helping her.
They have chosen fruits and vegetables and now they are helping each other cook.
He’s helping her cut the chosen vegetables.
Grandpa needs a helping hand, so he has chosen his wife.
The wife is helping her husband cook the dish they have chosen.
While he was helping cook, he was chosen to cut the peppers.

2-Point Responses
She will have to carry the baby unless she gets the stroller.
Mom must carry the clothes unless someone offers to help.
She will carry the clothes up the stairs unless she drops them.
She will carry the laundry unless it is too heavy.
She cannot carry all of the laundry unless she has a basket.
She can’t carry all that unless she gets help from her kids.
She will not carry the laundry unless she has to.
Laundry is difficult to carry unless you have a basket.
Unless her washer is working, she’ll have to carry the clothes to the laundromat.
Unless she finds a basket to put the clothes in, she will have to carry them.
Unless she gets help, she will have to carry all the laundry herself.
I have to carry my clothing upstairs unless I want my mom to yell at me.
The kids don’t help carry the laundry unless their mom asks them to.

2-Point Responses
Even though it had stopped raining, they both still carried umbrellas.
Even though it is barely raining, they are both using umbrellas.
Even though it is raining outside, people are still walking around.
Even though they have cars, they are walking to work.
Even though it rained, they didn’t get wet.

Whether or not can be used to mean regardless or whether.

2-Point Responses
Whether or not he has a magnifying glass, he can still see the butterfly.
Whether or not the boy realized it, he was looking at a monarch butterfly.
Whether or not the butterfly can see him, he can see the butterfly.
Whether or not the butterfly is small, the boy can still see it with the microscope.
Whether or not the butterfly likes it, the boy wants to play.
Whether or not the butterfly flies away, the boy is still fascinated by it.

Although they had requires past tense in the independent clause unless defined time periods are provided in both clauses.

2-Point Responses
Although they had shovels, it was still hard to dig.
Although they had tools, the work took a long time.
Although they had a lot of work to do, they got it done.
Although they had a sidewalk already, they decided to build a new one.
Although they had been digging all morning, there was still more work to do.
Although they had been working all day, the sidewalk was far from being done.
Although they had worked hard, it still wasn’t done.
Although they had a long day yesterday, they are still working today. [Time periods are specified]

Only if he requires the main clause to be inverted so that the subject comes after the verb.

2-Point Responses
Only if he is very sick will his mom let him stay home.
Only if he had a fever could he stay home from school.
Only if he was not sick could he go to school.
Only if he receives medication will he get better.
Only if he gets better can he go outside to play.
Only if he rests will the child get better.
Only if he listens to the nurse will his temperature go down.
Only if he had listened to his mother and brought a jacket in the cold would he not be sick.
Only if he hadn’t gotten sick would he be at school.

2-Point Responses
If he had some help, it would be easier to carry the boxes.
If he had had some helpers, he wouldn’t have had to carry all the boxes himself.
If he had something to help him hold all those boxes, that could be really helpful.
If he had a dolly, he wouldn’t have to carry the boxes.
If he had a rolling cart, his job would be easier.
If he had more boxes, the stack would topple.
If he had bigger muscles, carrying those boxes would be easier.
If he had sense, he would use a dolly.
If he had a box of cookies, I would take it.
htmlSnippets.scoringProcedure:
Scoring Procedure

The following procedures are recommended for scoring.

  1. Read through the scoring rules. Study the Structure and Word Form errors listed under Grammar Error Categories, so you are familiar with the kinds of errors to listen for when scoring Grammar. Refer to the Language Glossary chapter of the KTEA–3 Scoring Manual for definitions and examples of unfamiliar grammar terms.

  2. Apply the General Scoring Guidelines.

  3. Consult the item-by-item scoring examples for the most common response types and how to score them.

  4. Evaluate the response for Task criteria. If the response does not meet one of the criteria, you don’t need to evaluate the remaining Task criteria for that item.

  5. Score Task. Give credit for Task only if all Task criteria are met. Otherwise, score Task as 0.

  6. Evaluate the response for Grammar errors (even if Task = 0).

  7. Score Grammar. If you hear any grammar errors, score as 0. For this score, it does not matter if the error is a Structure error or a Word Form error.

  8. Perform Error Analysis (optional). Decide whether Grammar errors fall under Structure or Word Form (or both).
htmlSnippets.generalScoringGuidelines:
General Scoring Guidelines

Use Mainstream American English as the standard when scoring grammar.

Do not penalize for articulation errors (e.g., pronouncing splashing as spashing).

Score the final response. If an examinee makes a false start or corrects a previous response, score what you interpret as the final response. When you give instructional feedback on a teaching item by rephrasing the item prompt as What is happening in this picture? and the examinee gives a better response, score this as the final response.

Because punctuation is not provided in an oral response, independent clauses included as part of fused sentences or a run-on response may need to be parsed. If two or more sentences are given, or the response sounds like a fused sentence or a run-on with two or more independent clauses joined together, score according to the following procedure:

  1. Use your best judgment to parse the response into sentences. Independent clauses may be treated as separate sentences.

  2. Choose the best sentence for scoring both Task and Grammar. Choose a sentence that includes the Target Word(s), even if the sentence includes grammar errors. If each sentence uses the same number of Target Words, or if none of the Target Words are used in any of the sentences, then score the one sentence that earns the highest score for Grammar. 

Example A:  The girl splashes in the water. She might get wet.

Only the second sentence includes a Target Word, so the second sentence is scored (Task = 0 for omitting one of the Target Words; Grammar = 1 for correct Structure and Word Form).

Example B:  The girl splashing in the water. She might get wet.

Each sentence includes only one of the Target Words so the Task score is the same for both (0). The first sentence would earn a 0 for Grammar (Task = 0 for omitting one of the Target Words; Grammar = 0 for Structure [omitted word]) but the second sentence would score a 1 for Grammar (Task = 0 for omitting one of the Target Words; Grammar = 1 for correct Structure and Word Form). As a result, only the second sentence should be scored. 

Example C:  The girl is splashing in the water. She might get wet.

Each sentence includes one of the Target Words and earns the same score, so either sentence may be selected for scoring (Task = 0 for omitting one of the Target Words; Grammar = 1 for correct Structure and Word Form).

Task and Grammar are scored independently of each other. Try not to let poor performance in one category influence the score for the other category.

Some errors result in scores of 0 for both Task and Grammar for an item.

  • If an examinee doesn’t respond to an item, or if the response is incomprehensible (the meaning cannot be understood), score 0 for both Task and Grammar.

  • Misplacement of a part of the sentence can result in scores of 0 on both Task (because the sentence does not make sense) and Grammar (because the misplacement results in a sentence structure error).

Responses may be

  • in the form of statements, commands, or questions; or

  • stated in the first person (pronoun I), second person (pronoun you, or a command with an implied you as the subject), or third person.
htmlSnippets.taskCriteria:
Task Criteria

Score 1 point for Task only if all of the following criteria are met.

  1. Includes target word(s) (Items 7–28)

The response must include the target word(s) with no changes to the form of the target word(s).

Don’t penalize if the examinee uses the target word in possessive form or as part of a contraction (e.g., cat’s).

For items with a target word phrase, the phrase must be used exactly as presented. If the phrase was not used at the beginning of the response, or was altered in some way, score Task as 0.

  1. Includes noun/pronoun and verb

The response must include a verb and at least one noun or pronoun. The response may or may not be a complete sentence to earn the Task point.

For example, His eats is not a complete sentence because it lacks a subject, but it meets this Task criterion because it includes a pronoun and a verb.

This criterion requires the response to include sufficient content to allow the other Task scoring criteria to be applied fairly. However, it’s also designed to be grammatically lenient to avoid double penalizing fragments under both Task and Grammar.

  1. Related to the picture

Picture interpretation issues are not penalized, so inaccurate descriptions of the pictures are acceptable. In addition to describing the picture, an examinee may describe events leading up to or following what is pictured, or may use the picture to create a context for the response.

Most errors result from examinees getting off task and discussing previously shown pictures or other topics, even after appropriate redirection from the examiner.

  1. Logical and meaningful

The response must be logical and describe something that is possible. Do you understand what the response means? Penalize if there are multiple possible interpretations of a response and you are confused about what was intended.

Additionally, the target word(s) must be used in a familiar or typical way—even if the words are not used well. The response must demonstrate that the examinee has a basic understanding of how to use the target word(s) and what the word(s) means. Don’t penalize just because the target word(s) could have been used better. Ask yourself, “Is the target word typically used this way in English?”

Don’t penalize if the examinee confuses a target word with a homophone (e.g., peak for peek).
htmlSnippets.grammarCriteria:
Grammar Criteria

Score Grammar 1 point if the response contains no grammar errors. Grammar errors include all Structure and Word Form errors.

When you score each response, trust your first impression and try not to over analyze the response. If it sounds right, it probably is.

Don’t penalize just because a response could be improved in some way. Only penalize for responses that are obviously unacceptable in everyday oral expression.

If something doesn’t sound right and you can’t decide whether the response has a grammar error or is just awkward, ask yourself, “Is it acceptable to speak this way in English?” If not, it’s an error.

When scoring grammar, it is important that you focus only on the grammar of the sentence. Do not be distracted by the context of the sentence in relation to the picture. Some responses may seem incorrect either because they don’t accurately describe the picture or because you believe that the meaning of the response is not what the examinee intended. However, do not penalize the grammar because the sentence does not accurately describe the picture.
htmlSnippets.grammarErrorCategories:
Refer to the Error Analysis Scoring chapter of the KTEA–3 Scoring Manual for more information and examples of each category.

STRUCTURE

Sentence structure errors relate to how the sentence is organized. Structure errors include the following:

  • Fragment

A girl eating

  • Incorrect word order

The boy wants to know where is his chair.

  • Extra word(s)

Because he has a broken leg, so he can’t go out.

  • Omitted word(s)

Mommy is talking the phone.

The first steps, she walked all the way across the room.

  • Incorrect part of speech

She is sitting quiet. (quiet should be quietly)

The boy did great tying his shoes. (great should be well)

  • Did not identify the subject when the verb form changed

A boy is smiling and points to the clock. (Correct: A boy is smiling and he points to the clock.)

A boy is playing with his grandmother and is happy. (Correct: A boy is playing with his grandmother and he is happy.)

WORD FORM

Word Form errors involve the form (tense, agreement, plurality) or usage of a word.

In contexts where these words serve a broadly similar function, do not penalize when one of the following words is used in place of the other (accept either as correct): that vs. which; who vs. whom; lay vs. lie.

Word Form errors include the following:

  • Slang and colloquial word usage

Examples of errors include gonna, ain’t, anyways.

‘Til is an acceptable contraction for until.

  • Subject-verb disagreement

People is feeding the birds.

  • Incorrect verb form

He buyed the pizza.

  • Lack of parallel structure

While they played music, people talk.

  • Incorrect noun or pronoun, unclear pronoun, or missing possessive

A childs is doing homework. (childs should be child)

The boy and her mom are looking at birds. (her is unclear)

He picked up the little girl toy. (girl should be girl’s)

Do not penalize for

  • Using that to refer to a person (She was the one that fed the cat).

  • Using they or their to refer to a single person (A child is doing their homework).
  • Incorrect preposition or article

The girl is playing with her cat on the garden.

He asked for a iced tea.

  • Word meaning

Unless you don’t help, I will have to carry all the laundry. (unless is used to mean if)

If he had less boxes, it wouldn’t be so hard to carry them all. (less is used to mean fewer)

  • Double negative

She doesn’t want no more.
